content: The "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" establishes awards for schools under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to promote innovation in technology. The purpose of the "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" is to expand knowledge about advanced technology in education, address national questions about technology's impact on teaching, and develop innovative models for technology integration in education. The Secretary can award grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements for up to 5 years through the Office of Educational Technology to implement innovative technology in education aligned with academic standards. "Eligibility for grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements for implementing innovative technology in education aligned with academic standards is outlined in SEC. 3212." To be eligible for an award under this program, a consortium must include a State or local educational agency and an institution of higher education or other entity with relevant expertise. The application must describe the project and include a plan for independent evaluation. An eligible applicant must submit an application to the Secretary with a project description and a detailed evaluation plan. The Secretary may prioritize projects that develop innovative educational technology models. The Secretary may prioritize projects that develop innovative educational technology models, including distance learning networks, software, and online-learning resources. Priority is also given to projects serving multiple states, focusing on large-scale technology innovations, serving underserved populations, and requiring substantial financial and other resources from applicants. Priority is given to projects that serve traditionally underserved populations, develop innovative models for using electronic networks, and establish high-speed internet access. Applicants providing substantial financial resources are also prioritized. "SEC. 3213. USES OF FUNDS." "A recipient must use funds awarded under this part to develop new educational technology applications, integrate technology across the curriculum, and carry out other activities consistent with the purposes of this part, such as improving teachers' ability to integrate technology effectively." The recipient must use funds to develop innovative models for improving teachers' ability to integrate technology into curriculum and create high-quality digital content for challenging learning environments. The curr_chunk discusses web-based distance learning curricula, digital libraries, and software for educational material development. It also mentions using technology to make programs accessible to students with special needs. The curr_chunk focuses on the development, modification, and maintenance of educational materials. It includes using technology to make programs accessible to students with special needs, providing opportunities for female students to explore technology, and promoting school-family partnerships. The curr_chunk focuses on promoting school-family partnerships, acquiring connectivity linkages, and collaborating with other technology research programs. The Secretary is authorized to develop tools, provide resources, offer technical assistance, conduct independent evaluations, and disseminate findings related to evaluating the impact of educational technology on teaching and learning. The recipient of funds under this part is limited to using no more than 3 percent of the funds for administrative costs or technical assistance. The Secretary may require recipients of funds to share in the cost of activities assisted, not exceeding 50 percent of the total cost. The non-Federal share may be in cash or in-kind contributions, and the Secretary can increase this share after the first year of receiving funds. The required non-Federal share will be published in the Federal Register. "Authorization of appropriations for activities assisted by the Secretary may require recipients to share up to 50% of the total cost, in cash or in-kind contributions." "For fiscal year 2001 and the following four years, necessary sums are authorized to be appropriated. Repeal of former program for National Challenge Grants includes amendments to specific sections of the Act."
